page.title: 01Yealand Villages Today
page.content: The name Yealand probably derives from the Anglo-Saxon "geah-land" or steep land. It is mentioned in the original Domesday Book as "Jaland". Above the villages there is a limestone hillside covered with deciduous and yew trees. Lower down there are fields of intensive grassland, some grazed by cows and sheep, others cut for silage and hay. The adult population of Yealand is about 500 people. There are still a few people in farming but most are retired or work outside the villages. We have a village shop, a pub and three churches - Roman Catholic, Anglican and a Quaker Meeting House. It is three miles to the nearest town called Carnforth where the older children go to school. By Helen, David and Rachel
